column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Boston/Jamaica Plain-Mission Hill
#Text=Jamaica Plain
#Text=and Mission Hill are two distinct neighborhoods within the City of Boston .
#Text=They are grouped together here due to their shared border and transit options .
#Text=Jamaica Plain — or " JP " — is one of the first streetcar suburbs in America and is surrounded by many parks .
#Text=JP has undergone significant urban renewal since the turn of the century , with scores of fine shops and restaurants .
#Text=North of JP , tiny Mission Hill was named quite literally , when a large church was built atop a hill .
#Text=This small neighborhood is more urban feeling and has a high student population .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Historically , both neighborhoods were simple farming communities within Roxbury .
#Text=They became part of West Roxbury during the mid-19th century for a time , before finally being annexed by Boston in 1874 .
#Text=Around this time a small river , or stony brook , flowed along what is today the Southwest Corridor .
#Text=Taking advantage of the available hydropower , several industries sprang up along the route , most notably breweries .
#Text=Residents have used Centre St and Huntington Ave for almost 200 years to commute between these factories and downtown Boston .
#Text=Possessing a wealth of green space and many transit options , Jamaica Plain is very desirable among Bostonians .
#Text=The old brewery buildings have been remodeled and updated , while ever fancier shops and restaurants continue to open for business .
#Text=But JP draws its real strength from the diversity of its residents .
#Text=A strong character of social awareness and tolerance has mitigated gentrifications worst effects .
#Text=You can still find traditional bodegas mixed in with the upscale brunch spots .
#Text=Mission
#Text=Hill
#Text=came into its own around 1870 , after the construction of the eponymous Mission Hill Basilica .
#Text=Built and paid for by the mostly German congregation , the basilica is striking and can be seen in many views of Boston .
#Text=The neighborhood has changed drastically over the years .
#Text=Surrounded by hospitals and universities , it plays host to a frequently rotating cast of young people .
#Text=And the area affords some great views of the city from its high points .
#Text=Neighborhoods
#Text=These neighborhoods are listed from north to south .
#Text=You 'll find these larger nodes of activity to be separated by stretches of quieter , more residential areas .
#Text=Think of the area like a wide slice of residential buildings sandwiched between giant parks on either side .
#Text=Brigham Circle :
#Text=This is Mission Hill 's commercial heart .
#Text=Most of the neighborhood 's shops and restaurants can be found in this area .
#Text=Named after the nearby Brigham and Women 's Hospital , this is a transitional area of the city .
#Text=Head north or " inbound " to enter the Longwood Medical neighborhood in Fenway/Kenmore .
#Text=Head south-east on Tremont to continue along Mission Hill , passing the Basilica and eventually entering Roxbury .
#Text=If you 're feeling bold , head up Calumet Street and try to bluff your way into a house party .
#Text=Your youth and a little red cup camouflage is all you 'll need .
#Text=Hyde Square :
#Text=One of Jamaica Plain 's commercial districts .
#Text=Consisting of a tiny rotary and a bunch of fantastic restaurants and bars nearby .
#Text=Later , head east down Centre Street towards Jackson Square to experience JP 's " Latin Quarter " .
#Text=During the 70s and 80s JP was a largely hispanic area , and this section of town still reflects that today .
#Text=The Monument :
#Text=JP 's biggest and busiest commercial zone .
#Text=Heading north from the monument along Center Street affords the opportunity for great people watching and window shopping .
#Text=If the weather 's cooperating , head west to Jamaica Pond , or south-west to witness the amazing Arnold Arboretum .
#Text=South will take you to Forest Hills and into Roslindale , and east will take you to Franklin Park in Roxbury .
#Text=By public transit
#Text=Taking the Orange Line and walking is the premiere way to access these neighborhoods .
#Text=Roxbury Crossing
#Text=serves Mission Hill , while Jackson Square , Stony Brook , and Green serve Jamaica Plain .
#Text=Green is quite popular , allowing easy access to the main shopping district in one direction , and Franklin Park in the other .
#Text=Use Forest Hills when visiting the Arboretum , the entrance is just across the street .
#Text=The " E " branch of the Green Line trolley is another great way into Mission Hill .
#Text=Brigham Circle
#Text=is the last stop along its dedicated right of way , while Fenwood Road , Mission Park , and Back of the Hill are all street level stops .
#Text=Watch your step !
#Text=All trolleys turn around at Heath St , the terminus of the E branch .
#Text=If you 'd like to walk a little less , but wait a little more , use the #39 bus .
#Text=Starting in Copley Square in the Back Bay , these big buses run constantly down Huntington Ave following the path of the E trolley .
#Text=Continuing beyond Heath St and down Centre , they pass in front of every shop and restaurant in JP .
#Text=Fighting traffic , they eventually make it to Forest Hills station .
#Text=From Copley to Heath Street , it is arguable faster than the E branch ( and a little cheaper ) , but they come less frequently .
#Text=By bicycle
#Text=The Southwest Corridor Park , which begins at Back Bay Station , stretches all the way to Forest Hills .
#Text=It 's one of the best bike paths in the city .
#Text=It 's also great for novice cyclists , as the path is completely separated from cars and street traffic at all times .

#Text=The park runs above and alongside the Orange Line , so consider biking roughly equivalent to taking the T. There are places to lock your bike at all stations , and throughout the neighborhoods .
#Text=Many locals use bikes here , so you 'll never be far from a bike shop if you encounter mechanical issues .
#Text=By car
#Text=Like most other areas of Boston , driving in these neighborhoods is not a great idea .
#Text=Only consider driving if you 're visiting the Arboretum or Franklin Park , and strongly consider the T even then .
#Text=Mission Hill borders one of the most congested areas in the city , and traffic is often snarled here at all hours .
#Text=In Jamaica Plain , the main thoroughfare is called the " Jamaicaway " , or Jway .
#Text=This section borders the Emerald Necklace and can be particularly challenging for out of town drivers .
#Text=Prepare for high speeds , narrow winding roads , and a series of busy rotaries along this four-lane undivided boulevard .
